For the second method, you should have kept moving the pan with it directly in the focal point or close enough. The scorcher heats up too fast even for metals (that is why it can melt some almost instantly where it hits first), so to distribute that you need to keep moving where you're adding the head. Over (a relatively short) time, you will have stored enough heat in the pan, which will even out if you take it off completely or to a higher spot (i.e. still getting concentrated light, but in a more even, dispersed way. It probably works too if you leave it directly in that elevated spot for a much longer amount of time. It is basically the same idea of cooking on hot stones or a hot pre-heated (thick) cast iron pot or skillet - let the thermal mass absorb A LOT of heat evenly, then use the stored heat for the cooking action.

Great experiment.  Loved your video.  Method 2 should actually work better than method 1 but you need to make some changes.  Your iron skillet does not have enough mass for method 2.  Switch to a 14"-16" pan.  Iron is very slow to heat up but also slow to cool... so preheat it for about 30 minutes. (as I cant tell how long things take from the video...  once 25-30 min are over test the pan temp with a drop of avocado oil... if it smokes it must be hot.. around 520F  or sunflower oil 440F... If not need more heat) Then when you throw your steak on the bottom will sear from pan heat and the top will sear from solar heat.  I expect you will get it cooked in half the time as both sides are getting done at once... so watch that meat thermometer.  You may need to remove the pan from the sunlight occasionally to slow down the cooking after the searing is done.  On cloudy days the same approach should work wonderfully in your kitchen broiler :)

Obvious tips for cooking steaks:
1) Don't cook a steak to the point that it is done and then brown it - by the time it's done browning, you will have overdone your steak.
2) If the steak is thin, jack up the heat so that you can brown the surface before the inside goes overdone.
3) If the steak is thick, use lower heat so that you don't overcook the outside before the inside gets to temp.
4) Maillard reactions - browning - happens at temperatures between 280 F and 330 F. You don't want to cook your meat to this temperature all through it, of course, but cooking at 200 F is way too low.
